settings.gg-1Am1SKHT_text:
Week 3: Husband tried it "just to see." 

 

Week 4: He was on it every evening. 

 

Week 8: His back went out—reformer was the only thing that helped.

 

The jump board that came with it? Now he does his "cardio" without leaving the house. The Pilates ring and weights? Our teenage daughter started using them for her volleyball training.

 

When the whole family uses it, that $2,000 suddenly feels like the smartest money we ever spent.
settings.gg-Mdwlf8_K_text: May 24, 2025 By Anna W. | Certified Mom of Two | 2 minute read
settings.gg09x4ngOcH_text: 5. The Math Finally Set Me Free
settings.gg2Evxh1_j6_text: I was drowning. Not the dramatic kind—the slow, quiet kind where you wake up one day and realize you can't remember the last time you felt strong. Where "self-care" feels like another thing you're failing at.
settings.gg2hHdJxrTA_text: I finally found something that fits my actual life—not my Instagram life.
settings.gg2sQ1heyfT_text: The Gorgeous Investment I Almost Felt Too Guilty to Make
settings.gg4ZZGmhjPU_text: Turns out, when your equipment looks like a $2,000 work of art that was handcrafted just for you, you use it.
settings.gg5GlYeoGxf_text:
Look, I'm not special.

 

Just a mom who got tired of waiting for "someday" and finally did the math—the real math. The cost of another year feeling disconnected from your body. The price of that studio membership you'll never actually use.

 

Maybe you're reading this at midnight with 47 browser tabs open comparing reformers. Maybe you're telling yourself "after the holidays."

 

Here's what I wish someone had told me:

 

The perfect time doesn't exist. 

 

But the perfect solution might.
settings.gg8OoyVThmo_text:
My old gym routine: Get kids ready, drive 20 minutes, find parking, work out for 27 minutes, race back for pickup.

 

With my Elevé? Roll out of bed at 5 AM, walk 12 steps, start working out. No shoes required. No bra required. (Sorry, TMI.)

 

Those 40 minutes I used to waste commuting? That's two full workouts now.

 

The same studio-quality workout I'd pay $65 for. Bedroom-to-reformer in 30 seconds. Even my ADHD brain can't talk me out of that.
settings.ggDCTNtp4Dy_text:
Six months earlier, I would've laughed at this moment. Hell, I would've cried.
 

Because six months ago, I was the mom googling "how to feel like yourself again after kids" at 2 AM. The one who kept saying "I should have my shit together by now" while shoving toys under the couch before Zoom calls and pretending my leggings were "athleisure" when really they were just...surrender.
settings.ggGN7PqRDco_text:
Not including gas. Or babysitters. Or the emotional cost of rushing.

 

Suddenly, that Elevé reformer didn't look expensive. It looked like freedom.

 

And when I found out they only handcraft 50 per month—each one made specifically for its owner—it didn't feel like shopping anymore. It felt like being chosen.
settings.ggH2Fg0tfL-_text:
5-5:30 AM became sacred. No one needs snacks. No "urgent" emails. Just me and my reformer.

 

Twenty minutes. That's it. Not a 90-minute studio commitment. Just 20 minutes of studio-quality movement that somehow do more than hours at the gym ever did.

 

The 30-day program that came with it? Eliminated every "but I don't know what to do" excuse. Day 1, Day 2, Day 3... just press play and follow along. No thinking required at 5 AM.

 

The magic: Those 20 minutes ripple through everything. I'm calmer with the kids. Sharper at work. Less likely to lose it over LEGOs on the stairs.
settings.ggHVFFc6c8b_text: 2. Zero Commute Meant I Actually Showed Up
settings.ggK4YqD3uA5_text: 1. It's So Stunning, I Actually Want to Touch It Every Day
settings.ggL6RNTpvDW_text: 4. My Husband Started Using It (And Our Marriage Got Better)
settings.ggLYZ_fTVBs_text: Only 50 Elevé Reformers are crafted each month. If this page is live, one might still be available.
settings.ggMcxFt-8nx_text: Some things you can't put in a spreadsheet.
settings.ggNuUbPUH4C_text:
Listen, I know what you're thinking. Because I thought it too.

 

"Must be nice to drop $2,000 on a Pilates machine."

 

"She probably has a home gym and a nanny."

 

"I'd have abs too if I had that kind of time."

 

Here's the truth: I'm a marketing director with two kids under 8. My "home gym" is the corner of my living room between the couch and Emma's art supplies. I've hidden in my car to eat lunch in peace. I've cried over spilled milk—literally—at 6 AM after being up all night with a sick kid.

 

I've bought the $29 resistance bands that ended up holding my daughter's fort together. The yoga mat that became a craft surface. The gym membership I used exactly twice before the mom guilt kicked in because who has 90 minutes for a workout plus commute when your 4-year-old asks "why are you always leaving?"

 

That's when I started hate-watching Pilates reformer videos at midnight. (Don't judge—you've done weirder things during insomnia scrolling.)

 

Beautiful women on beautiful machines in beautiful studios. "$65 per class!" the websites shouted. Plus babysitter. Plus commute. Plus the anxiety of being the out-of-shape mom in the back.

 

Then I did the math that changed everything:
settings.ggQXaKrWLOg_text: From 'I Should Have My Shit Together' to 'Wait, Are Those My Abs?'
settings.ggT-zTB93Mi_text:
I was standing in my bathroom at 5:47 AM, trying to squeeze into my "good" jeans for a client meeting, when I looked down and literally said out loud:

 

"What the f*ck?"

 

Not the "I had abs in college" kind. Not the "if I suck in and turn sideways" kind. Actual, visible abs. At 37. After two kids. While working full-time.

 

I had to look again. Touch them. Make sure the mirror wasn't playing tricks.
settings.ggY1QoG1UOj_text: 3. It Gave Me 5 AM Back (And That Gave Me Everything)
settings.gg_76GaKrYV_text: Then I Did the Math That Changed Everything
settings.ggb0QYChwJd_text:
Studio Pilates: $65/class x 3 times/week = $10,140/year 

 

Babysitter: $20/hour x 2 hours x 3 times/week = $3,120/year 

 

Gas + Parking: $1,248/year 

 

Total: $14,508 per year

 

My Elevé Package: $2,000 once (down from $2,750)

 

Here's what blew my mind: It came with EVERYTHING. The reformer, yes, but also:

  • A 30-day program (no more "I don't know where to start")
  • Jump board & box (that's $400+ value right there)
  • Pilates ring, ball, 5lb weights (another $150)
  • Even the damn grip socks

I literally needed nothing else. Ever. Set for life for less than 2 months of studio classes.

 

But the real calculation? What's it worth to actually want to work out? To have my husband say "you seem happier"? To catch your abs in the mirror and think "holy shit"?
settings.ggbzw4dDG5d_text: The Mom Who Googled Her Way Through Midnight Anxiety
settings.ggezJeX7dH__text: Sometimes the most expensive thing isn't the price tag. It's what it costs you to keep putting yourself last.
settings.ggfMLOslev1_text: The 5 Realizations That Finally Made Me Hit 'Add to Cart' at 1 AM
settings.ggfn3U23ZCX_text: I Looked Down and Said 'What the F*ck'
settings.ggiHdU6pNbx_text: After weeks of agonizing, filling my cart and abandoning it, reading every review twice—these are the thoughts that changed everything:
settings.ggjs2QHMhgb_text:
The Elevé reformer sitting in my living room? I almost returned it three times that first week. Even at $2,000 (marked down from $2,750), the guilt was eating me alive. That money could've been dance lessons for Emma. Part of our vacation fund.

 

But here's what nobody tells you about that moment when you finally choose yourself—when you stop apologizing for wanting something beautiful, something that's just yours, something that doesn't require a babysitter or a 30-minute drive to a studio that smells like other people's sweat...
settings.ggo6-hw-siL_text: Try it today with a 30-Day Money Back Guarantee!
settings.ggobmRH9OIq_text: The $2,000 Purchase I Almost Returned Three Times
settings.ggpWK1kyDmk_text: Studio classes: $65 x 3 times per week x 52 weeks = $10,140 per year
settings.ggys100qsA8_text:
I bought the Elevé because it was beautiful. Oak wood, clean lines—my mother-in-law asked if it was a new console table, lol.

 

Here's what I didn't expect: Beauty became accountability.

 

Those ugly resistance bands in my closet? Easy to ignore. But this gorgeous piece in my living room? I'd walk by and think, "I should use that beautiful thing."

settings.gg2U0rhOw13_text: "It’s like a sanctuary in the middle of my living room."
settings.ggEyHa-UPkT_text: "It’s not loud. It’s not bulky. It doesn’t demand anything from me. I step on, I move with intention, and I feel better. This reformer brought back a version of me I didn’t know I was allowed to reclaim."
settings.ggVFyU1ycAv_text: "The only thing that’s stuck in my routine since having kids."
settings.ggiOigIfOAM_text: "She said, ‘Mommy, can I do that with you?’ It’s not just about fitness. It’s about showing up for myself in front of my kids. I finally feel like I’m setting the example I’ve always wanted to.
settings.ggkKVuN56aC_text: "My daughter joined me on the reformer. I cried."
settings.ggkM2FpAeqX_text: "I’ve bought apps, mats, subscriptions, you name it. Nothing ever lasted more than a week. But the Elevé? I’ve used it almost every day for two months. It feels like therapy for my body, and it’s the only thing I look forward to after the chaos of mornings."
settings.ggvFVWKzP1G_text: "I hesitated at first because it’s an investment. But I realized I was spending more on studio memberships I couldn’t use and impulse buys trying to ‘feel better.’ This actually works. It’s beautiful, it’s calming, and I feel stronger and more in control again."
